Sentence: CAIRO - At least three people were killed and hundreds were injured across Egypt on Friday, as anti-government protesters ransacked Muslim Brotherhood offices and tens of thousands of supporters and opponents of President Mohammed Morsi held dueling rallies in the capital.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: While the protests in Cairo remained peaceful, deadly clashes erupted in the port city of Alexandria, where protesters set fire to the Brotherhood’s headquarters.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Security officials said that among the victims was a U.S. citizen, a man stabbed to death near the headquarters.
Label: Main

Sentence: The security official said it was not clear who had attacked the man, and the official was not able to provide information about a second victim in the city.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: A State Department spokesman, Patrick Ventrell, confirmed that a U.S. citizen was killed in Alexandria but said he had no further information.
Label: Main

Sentence: The violence Friday provided a dark prelude to planned mass protests Sunday by Morsi’s opponents, who are demanding that the president step down and early elections be held.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Fears about possible violence at the marches have preoccupied the country for weeks and further split Egypt’s deeply polarized political class.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In recent days, both the army and Egypt’s highest religious authority have warned about the potential for deadly civil strife.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: On Friday, the United States warned its citizens to defer “nonessential” travel to Egypt and said it was allowing some of its embassy employees and their families to leave the country because of the political unrest.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: At least seven people have been killed in violent episodes over the past three days outside Cairo.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt’s largest Islamist party and the movement that brought Morsi to power, said several of its supporters were killed in attacks on its offices and on mosques.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In Cairo, tens of thousands of people took to the streets in competing protests that remained separate, and as a result, largely peaceful.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Anti-government protesters gathered in Tahrir Square, around the Defense Ministry and in front of the presidential palace, which has been ringed with new barriers, including concrete blocks and shipping containers.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Calls for Morsi to resign have intensified as Egypt lurches from crisis to crisis, the most recent one over the endless gas lines that have clogged roads around the country.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: MEXICO CITY - A former Mexican governor was sentenced Friday to nearly 11 years in prison in the United States after pleading guilty in New York to a federal charge of conspiring to launder millions of dollars in drug cartel bribes to allow cocaine to move freely through his state.
Label: Main

Sentence: Shortly after becoming the governor of Quintana Roo state - popular for its vacation resort Cancún - in 1993, Mario Villanueva Madrid, 65, made the kind of deal U.S. law-enforcement officials have suspected local officials of making more often than they are able to prove.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Prosecutors said Villanueva had agreed to let the Juárez cartel, then one of the largest and most powerful, to transport cocaine from Colombia through Quintana Roo and on to the United States in exchange for up to $500,000 per shipment.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Traffickers were free to unload drug shipments at a state government hangar of a local airport, Mexican authorities have said.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Villanueva - nicknamed El Chueco, or “the Crooked One” - spread his capital through banks in the United States, Switzerland and the Bahamas.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Mexican authorities first began investigating Villanueva while he was governor.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Days before his term ended in 1999, he disappeared, but was caught two years later in Cancún, where he was convicted on organized crime and corruption offenses, imprisoned and then extradited in 2010 to the United States, which had indicted him in 2001.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said he had more than $17 million in a number of U.S. accounts that had been seized, including one at Lehman Bros.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Villanueva pleaded guilty to the federal count in August.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “With his sentence today, Villanueva Madrid completes his descent from elected government official to corrupted official to incarcerated felon,” said Preet Bharara, the U.S. attorney in Manhattan.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Villanueva is the latest in a growing list of former Mexican governors making headlines over corruption allegations.
Label: Cause_General

Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Since then, the merger has sailed through regulatory approvals in the United States and Europe, as well as China, Canada and other countries.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The new company would have more than 10,000 employees, 250 independent publishing imprints and about $3.9 billion in annual revenues.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Markus Dohle, the chairman and chief executive of Random House who will take on the role of chief executive of the new company, announced the finalization of the merger in an email to employees Monday.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “Today, we are Penguin Random House,” he wrote.
Label: Main

Sentence: “You should be proud of what you’ve accomplished and what we are all now a part of: the first truly global trade book publishing company.

Sentence: Together, we are even better positioned to fulfill our core purpose: to bridge authors and readers by publishing the very best books.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Bertelsmann acquired Random House in 1998 for more than $1 billion.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: David Shanks, the chief executive of Penguin Group USA, has stepped down and will be a senior adviser to Dohle and the executive team, Dohle said in his letter to employees.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: John Makinson, the head of Penguin Group since 2002, will be the chairman of Penguin Random House.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: “Penguin Random House starts life today as a freshly minted company, but also as a creative enterprise that will draw on the greatest legacies in the history of book publishing,” Makinson said in a statement.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Over the last several months, executives at both companies have sought to assure employees on the publishing side that it will be business as usual.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: There are no immediate plans for laying off employees or shuttering imprints.

Sentence: Executives at Penguin and Random House said the initial focus would be on unifying the infrastructure of the companies, including establishing pay scales, health benefits and new email addresses.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: There will also be an effort to sort out redundancies.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: As physical book sales decrease, so does the need for gigantic warehouses to store and ship books; the newly combined company is likely to find ways to trim printing, distribution and storage costs.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: PARIS - Czech prosecutors asked the Parliament on Monday to strip former Prime Minister Petr Necas of immunity from prosecution.

Sentence: The chief of staff - Jana Nagyova, a close confidante of Necas - is accused of ordering the secret services to spy on Necas’ estranged wife, whom he is divorcing.

Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Prosecutors said they were examining whether Necas had links to the bribery scheme, which some analysts and supporters of Necas have dismissed as the routine trading of political favors rather than a criminal act.

Sentence: Necas said Monday that no agreement had been made with the three lawmakers, and that, in any case, political agreements could not be considered crimes.

Sentence: SEOUL, South Korea - South Korean factory managers returned Wednesday to a shuttered industrial park in North Korea for the first time in two months, as the two governments resumed talks on reopening the complex, once a symbol of inter-Korean economic cooperation.
Label: Main

Sentence: Sixty factory managers from the South arrived in the Kaesong Industrial Zone, in the North Korean border town of the same name, for a day trip to check on their factories, which have been idle since the last of the managers left in late April.
Label: Main

Sentence: North Korea halted production there in early April by withdrawing its 53,000 workers, in part blaming tensions it said were caused by joint U.S.-South Korean military drills at the time.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The managers inspected their manufacturing equipment before the possible resumption of operations.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: More managers planned to visit Kaesong on Thursday.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Representatives of the two Korean governments met on the border over the weekend and agreed upon the managers’ return, but they remained far apart over the terms of reopening the complex.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Suh Ho, the chief South Korean negotiator, said Wednesday that North Korea must accept “common sense and international standards” in Kaesong before the complex can be “normalized and further developed.”
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: South Korea is urging North Korea to take steps to assure that it will not let political and military disputes interfere again with the factory park’s operation.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: South Korean President Park Geun-hye has suggested that one step would be for North Korea to agree to invite non-Korean factories to Kaesong.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: The chief North Korean negotiator, Pak Chol-su, is pressing South Korea to agree to an early resumption of work at the complex, citing fears among factory owners that if their plants were not restarted soon, their equipment would start deteriorating in the monsoon season.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: The factory managers’ return and the continuing talks were a sign that tensions between the two Koreas were easing after months of hostile exchanges, which peaked when the North threatened to attack the South with nuclear weapons and the South responded with warnings of counterattacks.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The Kaesong complex, where textile and electronic parts companies from the South employed low-cost North Korean workers, started producing goods in late 2004.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: It is the last remaining toehold for South Korea’s efforts from a previous era to use economic cooperation to help the North open up and move toward the reunification of the peninsula.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: NEW YORK - When Joseph C. Massino took the witness stand in 2011, becoming the first official boss of one of New York’s five crime families to break the code of silence and testify against a former confederate, he offered a succinct explanation for his departure from mob tradition.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “I’m hoping to see a light at the end of the tunnel,” he said.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: On Wednesday, the tunnel got a whole lot shorter: A federal judge commuted Massino’s sentence of two consecutive life terms in prison.
Label: Main

Sentence: Massino, the former boss of the Bonanno crime family, will be released from federal custody in 60 days, a period the government requested to put in place security arrangements to keep Massino safe from what are presumed to be a considerable number of enemies.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn had sought a reduction of Massino’s sentence, citing his extensive cooperation: While incarcerated, Massino had recorded conversations with a Mafia captain, and he has provided investigators with information about hundreds of people associated with not only the Bonanno family, which Massino took control of in 1991, but also the other crime families across New York.

Sentence: At a brief hearing in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn on Wednesday, Judge Nicholas G. Garaufis credited the government’s arguments and decided to undo the sentence of two life terms that he had originally meted out to Massino.

Sentence: When that sentence was handed down, in 2005, clapping could be heard in his courtroom.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: But on Wednesday, the judge said that in deciding to free Massino after more than 10 years of incarceration, he had considered the aging mobster’s “extraordinary cooperation with the government and his willingness to place himself at grave personal risk.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Once released, Massino will probably receive a new identity and live elsewhere in the United States, his lawyer, Edward A. McDonald, said after the hearing.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: McDonald said that Massino could support himself on rental income from his property and that he was also eligible for Social Security income.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Garaufis said that Massino, a rotund man of 70 whose health is failing, “may be the most important cooperator in the modern history of law enforcement efforts to prosecute the American Mafia.” He said that Massino’s assistance was essential in the investigations of the four leaders of the Bonanno family who followed him.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The judge also noted that Massino’s willingness to turn informer “has almost certainly caused numerous other members of organized crime to cooperate with the government.”
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Massino’s own crimes received only passing mention on Wednesday.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: He has been convicted of eight murders, including those of several rivals in the Bonanno family.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Massino, who wore a two-toned sweatsuit, said little during the hearing, leaving most of the speaking to his lawyer.

Sentence: But Massino did offer a brief statement of remorse, which he delivered standing in a single breath, and then quickly sat down.

Sentence: “I pray every night for forgiveness of everyone I hurt, especially the victims’ families,” he said.

Sentence: A prosecutor, Taryn A. Merkl, said that the government had reached out to the families of Massino’s victims to inquire if any wanted to make a statement in court, but had not received any responses.

Sentence: Merkl said that nothing about the government’s decision to take Massino’s side “apologizes or condones the life he led, yet at the same time he decided to make a change.”

Sentence: Details of the life Massino will lead after his release were scarce.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Garaufis said Massino’s age and ill health reduced “the court’s concern about possible recidivism.” Nonetheless, he ordered that Massino not associate “for the rest of your life” with known organized crime figures.

Sentence: McDonald described his client as “a stoic guy,” but said Massino often told him that “if he had to make the decision again, if he was 18 or 19 years old, he wouldn’t go into the Mafia.”

Sentence: LOS ANGELES - Just six months after declaring that “the prison crisis is over in California,” Gov.
Label: Main

Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: LOS ANGELES - The police here were preparing for another night of protests on Tuesday, and community activists were working to maintain the peace after anger over the acquittal of George Zimmerman in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin turned violent in South Los Angeles on Monday night.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: A group of about 150 mostly young people broke away from a peaceful demonstration in the Crenshaw district, long home to many of the city’s black residents.
Label: Main

Sentence: Protesters ran through the streets, blocking traffic, hitting cars, assaulting pedestrians and ransacking businesses, the police reported.
Label: Main

Sentence: Hundreds of police officers in riot gear descended on the area to quell the unrest.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Fourteen people were arrested, the police said, half of them juveniles.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Two decades after the acquittal of white Los Angeles police officers in the beating of Rodney King sparked deadly riots in the same part of the city, residents and public officials agreed that the more muted anger over the Zimmerman verdict in Florida - and the much smaller outbreak of violence - showed how much, and how little, has changed.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Twenty-one years ago we witnessed what could happen when there’s a reaction to a verdict,” Mark Ridley-Thomas, a Los Angeles County supervisor who represents South Los Angeles, said at a news conference on Monday night.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Similar sentiments are being expressed here in this space, but the response of the LAPD is qualitatively different.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Many in the neighborhood, while remaining wary of law enforcement officials, agreed that relations between black residents and the Police Department had vastly improved.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The police allowed the demonstration to continue until the violence began.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “The police did a top-notch job,” said Trebien Bellows, 46, a lifelong neighborhood resident.
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: “I have to give it up for the new police chief.
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: Before things got crazy, they jumped right on it.” Charlie Beck was appointed police chief in 2009.

Sentence: The unrest in Los Angeles followed consecutive nights of largely peaceful protests in cities like Atlanta, Chicago, New York and Washington.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In Oakland, Calif., demonstrators blocked traffic along Interstate 880 for a brief period during the afternoon rush Monday before authorities were able to clear the road.

Sentence: KIROV, Russia - Alexei A. Navalny, a lawyer who became Russia’s most resonant opposition voice by crusading against rampant public corruption, was found guilty Thursday of stealing money from a state-controlled timber company.
Label: Main

Sentence: He was sentenced to five years in prison - a punishment that immediately transformed Navalny, 37, who recently declared his candidacy for mayor of Moscow, from an opposition activist to a political dissident and prisoner.
Label: Main

Sentence: Navalny - who became an irritant to President Vladimir Putin by branding his United Russia political machine as the “party of swindlers and thieves,” - was the first to use the Internet and social media as his main weapon against the state.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Navalny’s co-defendant, Pyotr Ofitserov, a businessman and acquaintance who worked with him on the timber project, was sentenced to four years in prison.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The two men, who had been accused of embezzling nearly $500,000, were also each fined more than $15,000.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Much of the judge’s findings was based on the testimony of a third man accused in the scheme, Vyacheslav Opalev, who pleaded guilty and worked with the prosecution.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: In his decision, Judge Sergei Blinov called his testimony trustworthy and reliable.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But during the trial, Opalev at times gave contradictory evidence, and defense lawyers were not allowed to cross-examine him.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: In addition, Blinov barred the defense from calling 13 witnesses.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The verdict quickly reverberated throughout the highest levels of Russian government and society and even sparked some calls for boycotts of the Moscow mayoral election and future national ballots.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Alexei L. Kudrin, a close associate of Putin and former finance minister, described it on Twitter as “looking less like a punishment than an attempt to isolate him from social life and the electoral process.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The crime novelist Boris Akunin, who is also a political opposition leader, said the verdict showed there was little hope to change Russia by democratic means.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Lifetime deprivation of elections - this is what the verdict means not only for Navalny but for all who thought it was possible to change this system through elections,” Akunin wrote.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: As the five-year sentence was delivered, and the judge said that it could not be suspended but required actual jail time, some of Navalny’s supporters burst into tears.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: He was led away in handcuffs.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In Moscow, even before the sentence was announced, supporters and the police began to gather at Manezh Square near the Kremlin where backers of Alexei Navalny had planned to hold an unsanctioned rally.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: More than 7,000 people had responded to an announcement of the event on Facebook to say that they would attend.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The city of Detroit, which has filed for bankruptcy, has formally hired the international auction house Christie’s to appraise part of the city-owned art collection held by the Detroit Institute of Arts, the auction house said Monday.
Label: Main

Sentence: A decision about whether to sell the art to satisfy creditors has not been made, city officials have said, although all the city’s assets are being evaluated in light of the situation in Detroit, the largest U.S. city ever to file for bankruptcy.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Christie’s representatives had previously visited the museum in early June and confirmed Monday that the company had been hired to appraise the collection but gave no details about which portion of the collection it would be looking at.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “Christie’s was asked to assist due to our expertise in this area across all fine art categories and eras,” it said in its statement.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: It said, “In addition we will also assist and advise on how to realize value for the City while leaving the art in the City’s ownership.”
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: The office of Detroit emergency manager Kevyn Orr will pay Christie’s $200,000 for the appraisal, which is expected to be completed by mid-October, the Detroit Free Press reported on its website.

Sentence: Christie’s will appraise only artworks that are clearly owned by the city and that are not bound by donor restrictions that might rule out a possible sale, the newspaper said, citing Orr’s spokesman Bill Nowling.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: ROME - A visibly shaken Silvio Berlusconi, the former Italian prime minister, said Sunday that his center-right party would continue to support Italy’s fragile coalition government, releasing some of the political tension that has built in the country since a court upheld his conviction for tax fraud last week.
Label: Main

Sentence: “We have said clearly and directly that the government must forge ahead and approve the economic measures that we have requested and were agreed,” Berlusconi said in his first public appearance since the conviction, speaking at a rally his party had organized in front of his residence here.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Italy’s prime minister, Enrico Letta, watched the rally on television and took note of Berlusconi’s intentions.
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: But he made clear that he expected concrete action, like support for a package of economic measures that are scheduled to be voted on in Parliament next week, a member of Letta’s staff said.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: “I can promise you,” Berlusconi told his supporters, almost in tears.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Here I am.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: I am staying here.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: I won’t surrender.”
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: An estimated 2,000 people attended the rally to express anger and bewilderment at the ruling.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “This party carries 10 million votes,” Raffaele Fitto, a former government minister from Berlusconi’s People of Liberty party, told the television network La7 from the rally.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “It cannot be canceled with a pen stroke.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Last week, Italy’s highest court upheld a four-year prison sentence for Berlusconi, which had been effectively reduced to one year, for tax fraud.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: He was found guilty of a plot in which his Mediaset broadcasting company bought the rights to show U.S. movies on their networks and inflated the prices, using offshore companies to evade taxes.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: After the ruling, lawmakers from the People of Liberty party offered to resign and have been demanding that President Giorgio Napolitano pardon Berlusconi, but experts say that is highly unlikely.

Sentence: By Oct. 15, Berlusconi must decide whether he prefers to serve his time in jail, under house arrest or do community service.

Sentence: SAN FRANCISCO - T-Mobile US, the fourth-largest U.S. carrier, lost thousands of customers over the past few years to rivals that offered cooler phones.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: But it appears to be getting its groove back.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The company Thursday said it had gained 1.1 million customers, including 685,000 contract subscribers, over its second quarter.
Label: Main

Sentence: That compares with losing 557,000 contract subscribers, the most valuable type of customer, in the same period a year ago.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The uptick represents its largest customer growth in four years.
Label: Main

Sentence: The company, based in Bellevue, Wash., only started offering the iPhone in April, when it also began offering new phone plans that address common frustrations with wireless companies, like confusing contracts and expensive data plans.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: “By fixing the things that drive them mad, like contracts and upgrades, and freeing them from the two-year sentences imposed on them by our competitors, they are choosing the new T-Mobile in unprecedented numbers,” John Legere, the chief executive of T-Mobile US, said in a news release.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Over the past several years, T-Mobile lost many customers largely because it lacked the iPhone, and customers were unhappy with its service.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But this year has been jam-packed with change for the company: It finally landed a deal with Apple to sell the iPhone, it began an overhaul of its network and it started offering lower-cost plans to lure customers from competitors.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The company also has extra muscle from its merger with the smaller carrier MetroPCS, which was completed in May.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The change is costing T-Mobile.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The company posted a loss of $16 million for the quarter, compared with a profit of $207 million last year in the same period.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But it also reported revenue of $6.23 billion, up from $4.9 billion last year.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The net income was above the expectations of Wall Street analysts.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: They had expected revenue of $6.01 billion, according to a survey by Thomson Reuters.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In March, T-Mobile discontinued two-year contracts, instead allowing customers to buy a smartphone for a lower upfront cost and adding the cost of the device to their monthly bill.

Sentence: It also continued to offer plans with unlimited data, an option that the top two carriers, Verizon Wireless and AT&T, killed years ago.

Sentence: In general, T-Mobile’s plans are also cheaper than its competitors’ - for $70 a month, a customer can have unlimited minutes, text messages and data.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The plans offered by AT&T and Verizon cost upward of roughly $100 a month.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: T-Mobile expects the growth to continue.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: For the full year, it said it expected to add between 1 million and 1.2 million contract subscribers.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: LONDON - To the Italian police, he was Domenico Rancadore, or “the professor,” a Mafia boss on the lam as a dangerous fugitive for almost two decades, a onetime enforcer for the Sicilian Cosa Nostra.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: To those who lived near him on a leafy street in a bland West London suburb, he was Marc Skinner, a father of two, a former teacher and a good neighbor who spent contented hours buffing the paint jobs on his fancy cars.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But this week, his double life began unraveling.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: A British judge denied him bail Friday, two days after his arrest on an international warrant seeking his extradition to Italy to serve a seven-year sentence for extortion and other crimes.
Label: Main

Sentence: Right until the brief court hearing Friday, there had been speculation that he would be freed because of technical flaws in the warrant.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: At a separate hearing the day before, Judge Quentin Purdy of Westminster Magistrates’ Court said, “There are concerns about the validity of the warrant that has come before the court.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But Friday, while Rancadore, 64, was still in a police holding cell, a new warrant was issued.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: At the court hearing later, Purdy denied his bail request, meaning that Rancadore will remain in custody while he awaits extradition proceedings.
Label: Main

Sentence: According to court filings in London, Rancadore was sentenced in 1999 to seven years in prison after being tried in absentia and convicted of extortion, membership in the Mafia and other serious crimes.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The Italian authorities placed him on a list of “dangerous fugitives,” the Italian Interior Ministry said, because he had been a “man of honor” in Cosa Nostra.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: As a top Mafia member, the Italian authorities said, Rancadore went by the sobriquet U Profissuri, the professor, from a Mafia clan in Trabia near Palermo, the Sicilian capital.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Italian investigators believe that Rancadore fled Italy in the early 1990s because of an internal conflict, when the “boss of all bosses,” Salvatore Riina, ordered the killing of two top anti-Mafia prosecutors.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The Italian police issued an international arrest warrant in 1998.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: For almost two decades, Rancadore lived in England under the assumed name of Marc Skinner, using the maiden name of his wife, Anne, and leading an innocuous life in London’s outer fringes, far from the perennial battle in Sicily between the authorities and the mob.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Joan Hills, 76, who lives nearby, told The Independent that Rancadore was “one of the best neighbors you could ever have.”
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: JERUSALEM - Israel published bids Sunday for the construction of more than 1,000 housing units in contested areas of East Jerusalem and several large West Bank settlements, intensifying the already charged atmosphere three days before the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks here and hours before Israel was to announce the names of Palestinian prisoners to be released this week.
Label: Main

Sentence: While the planning and building of settlements have continued in the months preceding the talks, causing constant friction, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new governing coalition had so far refrained from issuing construction bids since it was formed in March.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The publishing of bids is the final bureaucratic stage before new construction can begin.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Uri Ariel, the housing minister, announced the contentious move while Netanyahu was recovering in a hospital after overnight surgery for a hernia.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “The government of Israel is working to bring down the cost of living in all parts of the country,” Ariel, a member of the pro-settlement Jewish Home Party, said in a statement.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “No country in the world accepts dictates from other countries about where it is allowed to build and where not,” he continued, responding to the international condemnation of Israel’s continuing efforts to build up the settlements.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The prime minister’s office offered no immediate comment.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The settlement move appeared intended to appease the right-wing members of the Israeli government ahead of the expected release this week of 26 Palestinian prisoners who have served 20 years or more in prison for deadly attacks against Israelis.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Later on Sunday, a ministerial committee was expected to complete the list of those to be released on Tuesday.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The decision to release 104 prisoners over the coming months is deeply unpopular in Israel.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Netanyahu has explained it as a gesture that was necessary to persuade the Palestinian leadership to agree to resume long-stalled negotiations and that was preferable to acceding to other Palestinian demands like a settlement freeze.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But it appears that the talks Wednesday will be taking place amid a storm of mutual recrimination.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Muhammad Shtayyeh, a senior Palestinian negotiator, issued a statement Sunday saying, “It is clear that the Israeli government is deliberately attempting to sabotage U.S. and international efforts to resume negotiations.” Israel, he continued, “continues to use peace negotiations as a smoke screen for more settlement construction.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: BEIJING - In a city brimming with look-at-me architecture, the sprawling addition that Zhang Biqing, a health care magnate, built atop his 26th-floor apartment is a showstopper.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Constructed with ersatz boulders, crisscrossed by trellises and walkways and dotted with the occasional shrub, the two-story aerie resembles the idealized mountains depicted in classical Chinese paintings - except the requisite lonely monk of yore has been replaced by a flashy karaoke parlor.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The entire 8,000-square-foot addition, as it turns out, is illegal.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: On Monday, The Beijing Morning News featured a front-page photograph of Zhang’s garish rooftop expansion, along with disturbing accounts of how the well-connected entrepreneur blithely ignored his neighbors’ complaints during the six years he spent creating his craggy villa atop a luxury gated complex in western Beijing.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Tenants were so tortured by the din of nonstop construction - and the resulting leaks and cracked walls - that several of them sold their apartments and moved out.
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: One next-door neighbor was reportedly beaten up after he confronted Zhang about the project, which is said to have cost more than $4 million.
Label: Distant_Anecdotal

Sentence: The story, zealously covered by much of the Chinese news media on Tuesday, seemed to embody the popular perception that the rich and powerful can simply do as they please.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: According to news reports, Zhang amassed a fortune through a chain of traditional Chinese medicine clinics he owned, or through private acupuncture sessions.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Until recently, he was a local delegate to the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference, an advisory body to the ruling Communist Party.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Code enforcement officials said they were stymied by Zhang’s refusal to let them into his apartment.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The deputy head of the Purple Bamboo Park urban management district said he even dispatched inspectors to the building’s underground parking garage but Zhang managed to evade them.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “If we can’t calculate the scope of this illegal construction, we can’t issue a notice requiring him to dismantle it,” the official told the paper.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: By Tuesday, however, Zhang appeared to run out of luck.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Officials slapped a notice on his front door, giving him 15 days to remove the addition or present evidence that it had been legally constructed.
Label: Main

Sentence: He claimed the structure was safe in a brief interview Tuesday evening, but conceded that it might have been a folly after all.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Now I realize it was a huge mistake,” he said, adding that he would dismantle the addition within a week.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: SEOUL, South Korea - An American tour operator imprisoned in North Korea on charges of plotting to harm the Socialist country through Christian missionary activities has appealed to Washington to send a high-ranking official to North Korea to help free him, according to a videotaped interview made public Tuesday.
Label: Main

Sentence: The Choson Sinbo, a pro-North Korean newspaper based in Japan, on Tuesday posted the video footage of tour operator, Kenneth Bae, a Korean-American from Washington state, sitting in a hospital in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, where he was moved from a labor camp a week ago as his health deteriorated.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Bae, 45, had been imprisoned at the camp since May, shortly after he was sentenced to 15 years of hard labor for what North Korean authorities said were hostile acts against the government.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Bae was leading a group of visitors from China into the special economic zone of Rason in northeastern North Korea when he was arrested in November.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: North Korean officials accused Bae of being a Christian missionary who flouted the country’s laws on proselytizing.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: In his interview with The Choson Sinbo, Bae said he had “violated” North Korean laws.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “As an American citizen, I request the U.S. government to make active efforts so I can be pardoned and return home,” he said in the interview, which The Choson Sinbo said took place Friday.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “I think that a high-ranking U.S. official should come here and bring me home, and that such an official should come here as a representative of the U.S. government and apologize and make a request of an early pardon for my release.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: It was unclear whether Bae was speaking of his own free will.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: North Korea had previously said Bae would not be used as a bargaining chip.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But outside analysts said the recent news of his deteriorating health and the letters he was allowed to send to his family in recent weeks, along with another videotaped interview broadcast by The Choson Sinbo and CNN last month, were probably efforts by the North Korean government to force Washington to engage in dialogue.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In the past, the North has used Americans held on criminal charges to bring about visits by prominent U.S. figures seeking their release, like former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton - a practice that Washington has wanted to end.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: A visit by a high-ranking U.S. government representative would be a significant diplomatic coup for the North Korean government, which has long wanted an official dialogue with the United States.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Washington has insisted that there will be no such engagement until the North has shown concrete signs of giving up its nuclear weapons development.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In the video, Bae was also shown being visited by a Swedish diplomat.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Washington has no official diplomatic ties with North Korea, and the Swedish Embassy in Pyongyang represents U.S. interests in Bae’s case on Washington’s behalf.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Bae appeared gaunt in the video and said his various ailments, including a backache, had worsened during his time in the labor camp.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The State Department has called on the North to grant Bae amnesty and immediate release.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Jacques Vergès, the French lawyer who embraced anti-colonial causes and the role of devil’s advocate on a world stage to defend war criminals, terrorists, dictators and other notorious villains of the 20th century, died Thursday in Paris.
Label: Main

Sentence: He was 88.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The cause was a heart attack at around 8 p.m. as he was preparing to dine with friends, according to his publisher, Éditions Pierre-Guillaume de Roux.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: He died in the Parisian house where the Enlightenment philosopher Voltaire once lived, the publisher said in a statement.
Label: Main

Sentence: “The ideal place for the last theatrical act that was the death of this born actor who, like Voltaire, cultivated the art of permanent revolt and volte-face,” the statement said, reflecting the lawyer’s reputation for asking disturbing questions on behalf of notorious clients.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Is a killer a terrorist or a patriot?
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Can laws be used to judge good and evil?
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: For more than 50 years, Vergès raised such questions in defense of clients who claimed to be acting for political causes, although they were charged with genocide, crimes against humanity, bombings, hijackings and the murder of innocents.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: They included the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie; the terrorist Ilich Ramírez Sánchez, aka Carlos the Jackal; and Cambodia’s Khmer Rouge head of state, Khieu Samphan.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Vergès also sought to defend former presidents Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who was executed for crimes against humanity, and Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who represented himself in a war-crimes trial but died before a verdict.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Like many of his clients, Vergès, the son of a Vietnamese woman and a French diplomat, was an enigma.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Assassins targeted him.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: There were hints of ties to secret services, to terrorists he defended and to Mao Zedong, Che Guevara and other revolutionaries.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: He was a confidant of Pol Pot, the tyrant blamed for the deaths of at least 1.7 million Cambodians.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: He married a terrorist he saved from the guillotine, but left her and his two children and disappeared for eight years.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: “He’s a slippery man,” director Barbet Schroeder, who made “Terror’s Advocate,” a 2007 documentary on Vergès and terrorism as a political weapon, told The New York Times in 2007.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: “You can never touch him.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He loves the mystery.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The reason is that there are certain things he cannot talk about.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He would be in deep trouble if the truth came out.”
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In a career that paralleled the postwar disintegration of colonial empires in Asia, Africa and the Middle East, Vergès rose to prominence in the late 1950s defending Algerians accused of terrorist bombings.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Instead of contesting the evidence of French prosecutors in court, he insisted that the defendants were resistance fighters in a just war of liberation and challenged the legal and moral legitimacy of the trials.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: While most of his clients were convicted, the trials drew international attention to Vergès, and long after Algerian independence in 1962 his tactics served as a blueprint for his cases, which became public platforms to indict France and other Western nations for what he called crimes of racist colonialism and the exploitation of Third World peoples.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In the late 1960s, Vergès broadened his horizons, defending Palestinians charged with attacks on El Al aircraft in Athens and Zurich.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He later represented members of the Red Army Faction in Germany, whose bombings he called the work of “soldiers in a noble cause.”
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Vergès’ most famous case was his defense of Klaus Barbie, the wartime Gestapo leader known as “the Butcher of Lyons” for his role in the torture, execution and deportation to death camps of thousands of French citizens.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: After years in hiding, during which he is believed to have assisted Western intelligence services, Barbie was extradited from Bolivia to France in 1983.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: At his war-crimes trial in 1987, Barbie walked out, refusing to hear testimony of his horrors.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: “My law is to be against all laws.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Jacques Vergès and his twin brother, Paul, were born March 5, 1925, in Ubon Ratchathani, Siam, now Thailand.

Sentence: Returning to Paris, he became a lawyer in 1955 and gained fame defending Algerian guerrilla fighters.

Sentence: CAIRO - The judicial authorities in Egypt have ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak, who has been detained on a variety of charges since his ouster in 2011, according to state media and security officials Monday.
Label: Main

Sentence: It remained possible, however, that the authorities would find other ways to keep him in detention.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The development threatened to inject a volatile new element into the standoff between the country’s military and Islamist supporters of the deposed President Mohammed Morsi as Egypt entered the sixth day of a state of emergency following a bloody crackdown by the military in which hundreds of people have been killed.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: It was unclear how Egyptians would respond to the release of a despised autocrat whose downfall united Mubarak’s secular and Islamist foes.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Just in the past 24 hours, the Egyptian government has acknowledged that its security forces had killed 36 Islamists in its custody, while suspected militants were reported Monday to have killed at least 24 police officers in an attack on their minibuses in the restive northern Sinai region.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Mubarak, 85, faces an array of legal challenges including allegations of corruption and a retrial on charges of complicity in the murder of protesters whose revolt forced his ouster in February, 2011.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: On Monday, Mubarak’s lawyer, Farid el-Deeb, said a court had ordered his release and he might be freed this week.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: But there was no official confirmation from the military-backed interim government that Mubarak would be released.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: News reports said that the ambush Monday occurred in a village near the town of Rafah and that three police officers had been wounded.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The attackers were initially depicted as Islamist militants firing rocket-propelled grenades at the police minibuses.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But there was some confusion, with later reports quoting officials who put the death toll at 25.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: There was no official confirmation of the events.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Ambassadors from the 28-member European Union planned to meet Monday to review the bloc’s relationship with Egypt, confronting a question of whether stability and security outweigh considerations relating to human rights and democracy.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In a radio interview Monday, William Hague, the British foreign secretary, said he did not accept that outsiders were powerless to influence events.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “But we have to do our best to promote democratic institutions, to promote political dialogue and to keep faith with the majority of Egyptians who just want a free and stable and prosperous country,” he told the BBC.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Rosalia Mera, a Spanish entrepreneur who had dropped out of school at 11 to work as a seamstress and went on to help start a global fashion empire, Zara, becoming the world’s richest self-made woman, died Aug. 15 in La Coruña, Spain.
Label: Main

Sentence: She was 69.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Her death was announced by Inditex, the holding company that owns Zara and seven other apparel concerns.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Spanish newspapers said she had a stroke on the Mediterranean island of Minorca on Aug. 14 and was flown to a hospital in La Coruña, in northwestern Spain, where she lived.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Forbes magazine ranked Mera as the richest woman in Spain this year and the 66th richest woman in the world.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: She ranked first among women who had acquired their wealth through their own efforts, rather than inheritance or marriage.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Her former husband, Amancio Ortega, with whom she started the company as an equal partner in 1974, is listed by Forbes as the world’s third richest man, with assets of $57 billion.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Mera’s wealth came from owning approximately 7 percent of Inditex stock, worth $6.1 billion.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Zara changed the apparel industry, chiefly by speeding up its mass-market response to new designs coming from the leading fashion houses in Paris, Milan, New York and other cities.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Zara could come up with its own variations on those designs and have them in stores within two weeks; previously, six months was the industry average.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: It accomplished this through what is known as vertical integration.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Zara designs, produces, distributes and sells its own lines in its own retail stores - 1,763 in 86 countries, including the United States.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: It uses no subcontractors or intermediaries and relies little on advertising.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Devotees of the Zara label include the Duchess of Cambridge, the former Kate Middleton.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Zara takes an extra step in getting daily feedback from its many stores.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The company can incorporate customer desires by modifying a design and shipping the new product out within days.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The company says it takes care not to violate copyright laws in following designer trends.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In 1985, Zara and its “fast fashion” model came under the corporate umbrella of Industria de Diseno Textil, or Inditex S.A., a conglomerate whose eight brand names, each with its own chain of stores, aim at specific markets.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Massimo Dutti, for example, targets urban cosmopolites, while Bershka is youth-oriented.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In 2001, when Inditex shares were first sold to the public, Daniel Piette, fashion director for Louis Vuitton SA, called it “possibly the most innovative and devastating retailer in the world.”
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Rosalía Mera Goyenechea was born on Jan. 28, 1944, in a working-class neighborhood of La Coruña, a port city in Galicia, a center of Spain’s textile industry.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Her father worked for a utility company and her mother for a butcher shop.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Mera skipped secondary school and in 1963 met Ortega, the son of a railroad worker and a maid who had left school at 13 to work as a delivery boy for a shirt maker.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: When they met, he was working at one clothing shop in La Coruña and she at another.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: They married in 1966.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In their living room, they began making quilted bathrobes and lingerie that Mera had designed.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The London newspaper The Independent said in its obituary of Mera that her lingerie designs were “a bit shocking at the time” but immediately popular.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The newspaper suggested that this new liberalism in undergarments reflected a slight breeze of change in the final years of the dictatorship of Francisco Franco.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The couple soon expanded the business, setting up manufacturing operations, employing hundreds and later opening their own store.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: At first they wanted to call the store Zorba after watching the 1964 film “Zorba the Greek.” But after discovering that there was a bar named Zorba two blocks away, and since they had already made the molds for the letters spelling Zorba for a storefront sign, they simply rearranged them to see what they could find.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: They settled on Zara.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The business eventually expanded to other Spanish cities, then to Portugal, then around the world.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The couple separated in 1986 and divorced in the 1990s.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Mera stopped working at Zara after the separation but remained on the board until 2004.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: She devoted more time to charity work, much of it through a foundation that she and her husband had set up to help disabled people.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Mera made $600 million from Inditex’s public stock offering in 2001 and diversified her investments, buying stakes in a fish-farming group, a company that looks for cancer treatments in ocean products, and the maker of a fingerprinting system for newborns.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: She was a major investor in the Bulgari Hotel in London.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: For years Mera could be seen in La Coruña at the movies or pubs.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: She was also politically active, speaking out against tightening Spain’s abortion laws and cutbacks to health care and education programs.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: She visited the camps of protesters against capitalism’s excesses, a precursor to the Occupy Wall Street movement in the United States.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Survivors include a son, Marcos Ortega, and a daughter, Sandra Ortega.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: SAN DIEGO - Mayor Bob Filner resigned Friday under a barrage of sexual harassment complaints, offering an apology to his accusers while still denying the allegations and blaming his downfall on “a combination of awkwardness and hubris.”
Label: Main

Sentence: “I never intended to be a mayor who went out like this,” Filner said before a packed City Council chamber, drawing sporadic applause from some supporters in the audience.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: His announcement came after a closed-door meeting of the City Council in which members considered a deal struck late Wednesday that paved the way for the mayor’s resignation.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: He is to step down Aug. 30.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “This is the toughest decision in my life,” said Filner, who devoted many of his comments to criticizing his political enemies and speaking of the vision he had for leading the city.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The council’s decision came after dozens of people packed the chambers to voice their opinion on a deal whose details they had no way of knowing.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Several residents supporting a recall effort urged council members to reject any deal that would give Filner money for his legal fees and damages.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But others sought compassion for Filner, citing his years of championing civil rights and the environment.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The resignation capped a tumultuous six weeks for San Diego.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Since Filner’s top communication aide first went public with her complaints of sexual harassment last month, 17 more women came forward with accusations against him.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The women who said they were harassed included a retired Navy rear admiral, a great-grandmother, a university dean and the former communications director, Irene McCormack Jackson, who filed a sexual harassment lawsuit against the mayor and the city.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Filner eventually apologized for what he called disrespectful behavior, but maintained that he had not broken any laws and that he wanted an impartial review of his actions to clear his name.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: His lawyers filed papers in court to move the lawsuit against him to Imperial County, just east of San Diego.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But calls for his resignation grew louder in recent weeks and organizers on Sunday started collecting signatures to force a recall election against him.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Organizers of the recall effort said Friday that they had more than 20,000 signatures, about one-fifth of what would be needed to qualify for the ballot.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Todd Gloria, the Democratic City Council president, who was part of the negotiations, will serve as acting mayor until a special election is held in the next 90 days.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: MEXICO CITY - A former colonel in the Salvadoran military accused of planning the killing of six Jesuit priests during that country’s civil war has been sentenced to 21 months in a U.S. prison for immigration violations.
Label: Main

Sentence: The sentence, handed down in Boston on Tuesday, could set the stage for his extradition to Spain, where he would be one of the few top-ranking officers to face trial in the 1989 killings.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Five of the six priests were Spanish, and Spain is seeking his extradition because it is unlikely that El Salvador - where an amnesty law has allowed other suspects in the crime to remain free - will prosecute him.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: If convicted in Spain, he could face up to 30 years in prison.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The former colonel, Inocente Orlando Montano, 71, was El Salvador’s vice minister of public safety at the time of the killings, which brought international condemnation.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: When he was arrested in 2011, he had been living in a Boston suburb for 10 years.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He pleaded guilty in September to charges of immigration fraud and perjury related to his application for temporary humanitarian status to remain legally in the United States.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Almudena Bernabéu, a lawyer with the Center for Justice and Accountability in San Francisco, which has pursued the case, said that the United States had indicated it would be amenable to extraditing Montano once he served his sentence for immigration fraud.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Extradition proceedings could take more than a year.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: “With the conclusion of this sentencing, the hope is that the United States will, in fact, revise and respond positively to the extradition request,” Bernabéu said.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Montano had been granted a special immigration status that shielded him from deportation, which he had received after lying about his military service and the date he entered the United States, prosecutors said.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: An assistant U.S. attorney, John A. Capin, argued that Montano came to the United States to avoid criminal prosecution for his role in the killings.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Montano’s lawyer said that an amnesty was in effect when he left El Salvador, making the former colonel, who he said faced economic hardship at the time, immune to prosecution in his home country.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Truth Commission report named Montano a participant in the plot to kill the priests, whom military officers suspected of collaborating with left-wing guerrillas.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: They, their housekeeper and her teenage daughter were killed in a raid on the Jesuit-run University of Central America in San Salvador.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In 2011, a Spanish National Court judge issued arrest warrants for 20 men, including Montano, suspected of participating in the slaying of the priests.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The judge also requested the extradition of 15 of the 20 - the main suspects - but the Salvadoran Supreme Court denied that request.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: “The sentence of 21 months sends a message to human rights abusers that they cannot seek safe haven in the United States and avoid accountability for their actions,” said a statement from the Center for Justice and Accountability.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: NEW YORK - The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of the city’s top public schools, mishandled the investigation into a large cheating operation there last year from the moment he was tipped off to it until state education officials became aware of it more than a week later, a city report issued Friday said.
Label: Main

Sentence: The principal, Stanley Teitel, retired last summer while the city’s Education Department was investigating his handling of the cheating, which involved more than 60 students using smartphones to receive answers for standardized city and state tests.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The report, issued by the Education Department’s Office of Special Investigations, said that after Teitel was tipped off by a student about the cheating, he set up a sting operation to catch the ringleader when he should have tried to pre-emptively thwart the cheating, including by enforcing the citywide ban on phones inside schools.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The report said that Teitel and an assistant principal, Randi Damesek, took too long to question students involved and did not report the cheating to state officials until eight days after catching the lead student, when reporters began inquiring about what had happened.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: “It is the conclusion of this office that due to a lack of foresight, candor and professional judgment, Teitel and Damesek failed to efficiently and effectively carry out the administrative duties entrusted to them during their handling of the 'cheating incident,' of June 2012,” the report said.
Label: Main

Sentence: It recommended that Teitel be barred from future employment in city schools, and the Education Department will follow that recommendation, Erin Hughes, a spokeswoman, said.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Teitel said Friday he had not seen the report and would not discuss its contents.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “No one sent me a copy of it,” he said, adding, “I am retired.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: I have been retired for over a year.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Efforts to reach Damesek were unsuccessful.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The Education Department will bring disciplinary charges against her and seek her firing “or, at the very minimum, a demotion,” Hughes said.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Besides its unflattering portrait of the leadership team at one of the most prestigious high schools in the country, the report also describes a 21st-century example of how students let others peek at their answers.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The ringleader, Nayeem Ahsan, referred to as “Student A” in the report, told investigators he used his iPhone to send answers to other students via text messages to “garner good will” among classmates, the report said, and perhaps get help from them in subjects he was weaker in.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The number of students involved who received his texts “grew and grew,” according to Ahsan’s account in the report.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: During the physics Regents exam, he told investigators, he waited until one proctor left the room and was replaced by a lax one who did not walk around.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Eventually, she fell asleep, he said, and he began sending out answers.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The proctor denied falling asleep.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: On June 16, a student emailed Teitel to say that Ahsan had “electronically assisted” several students on Regents exams and was set to do so again, the report said.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: In reaction to that message, Teitel “showed an extreme lack of judgment,” it said.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: He set up a sting operation for a June 18 language exam, placing a reliable proctor to catch Ahsan in the act, the report said.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: When the proctor did so, he notified Teitel, who took Ahsan and his phone out of the room.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: School staff members copied information from the phone to find out who else had been receiving answers.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Shortly after Ahsan left, the information on his phone suddenly disappeared; he told school staff members that he had just suspended his phone service, which they did not believe, the report said.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Teitel told Ahsan and his father, “There’s no way I’m keeping him” at Stuyvesant and told them to request a safety-related transfer to another school, which they reluctantly did, but education officials rejected it, saying his safety was not in jeopardy.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Dozens of students were suspended for several days and had to retake exams.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Nayeem spent his senior year at Forest Hills High School in Queens and graduated two months ago, according to his father.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Although the report is dated Nov. 5, its release was delayed until Friday, “because there were allegations of a 'culture of cheating,'” at Stuyvesant, Hughes said.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “We kept the investigation open and monitored until the end of the school year,” Hughes said.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “No further evidence was presented that warranted a change in the report, so the report was issued as is.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Maps released by Wynn Resorts on Wednesday indicate that all of the company’s proposed Mystic River casino development lies within Everett, bolstering the company’s claim that the City of Boston is not a host community for the project and therefore cannot block it.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But Mayor Thomas M. Menino’s administration was not ready to give up, saying the Charlestown neighborhood near the proposed development should get to vote on whether to accept the Wynn proposal.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: ''It is easy to draw lines on a map and circumvent the boundaries of the city, but that doesn’t circumvent the impacts to the city,'' said Menino’s spokeswoman Dot Joyce.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: ''The city will continue to fight for the full protection of Charlestown and the people of Charlestown.''
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Menino and Wynn are in an ongoing dispute over whether part of Wynn’s proposed resort is in Boston.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: If it is, Boston could be designated a host community for the project under state law, giving the city broad power over the development, including the power to kill it.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Boston’s claim rests with the odd shape of the city line, which darts across the Mystic River into the edge of the former Monsanto chemical site where Wynn intends to build.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: The state gambling commission brought the two sides together Wednesday to present their arguments at a public forum.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: After hearing both sides -- and seeing Wynn’s maps -- the panel gave the combatants until the end of the week to solve the dispute on their own, or the commission would solve it for them at a more formal hearing with witnesses, cross examinations, and documents entered into evidence.
Label: Main

Sentence: Commission members did not directly say Wednesday which side they believed to be right, but suggested the documents provided by Wynn should help solve the dispute.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: ''It looks to me the facts are pretty clear,'' said commission chairman Stephen Crosby.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Wynn is competing for the sole Greater Boston casino Âlicense with Suffolk Downs, the East Boston casino proposal Âfavored by Menino, and a Foxwoods project in Milford.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The commission is expected to choose the winning applicant in early 2014.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Wynn’s representatives, including former governor William F. Weld, a partner at Mintz Levin, argued that the City of Boston, while not a host community, probably qualifies as a surrounding community under the law.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: As a surrounding community, the city could negotiate with Wynn for compensation to address the effects of a casino, such as additional traffic on Boston streets.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Surrounding communities, however, do not hold binding public votes on casino projects, nor can they block a casino development by refusing to negotiate or by asking for too much.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Failed negotiations would be settled through arbitration.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: ''There is nothing personal here,'' Weld said.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: ''We want the City of Boston to receive fair compensation for any impacts.''
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In presenting the city’s case, lawyers for Boston displayed Wynn’s own renderings of the project, which appear to show landscaping on a narrow triangle of land on the Boston side of the city line.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The city also claimed Wynn created confusion over Boston’s status by refusing to provide project plans and documents the city had requested.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Wynn’s representatives said artistic renderings should not be taken as formal plans.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Lawyers representing the two sides swapped business cards after the hearing, which Crosby took as a positive sign they would be talking about a resolution, without further action from the commission.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: SEOUL, South Korea - The children of a former military dictator of South Korea, Chun Doo-hwan, said Tuesday that they will pay 167 billion won ($154 million) that their father owed the government in fines.
Label: Main

Sentence: Their decision closes a chapter on South Korea’s prolonged struggle with the legacy of one of its most brutal former leaders.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: Chun, then an army major general, came to power in a coup in 1979 following the assassination of another military-backed strongman, President Park Chung-hee, who was the father of the current South Korean leader, President Park Geun-hye.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Chun ruled until 1988, when he was succeeded by Roh Tae-woo, his partner in the 1979 coup.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: After South Korea’s transition to democracy, both Chun and Roh were convicted on charges of treason for their roles in the coup and a 1980 military crackdown on a pro-democracy uprising in the southern city of Kwangju that left hundreds dead.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: They were also convicted of collecting huge bribes from big business while in office.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In 1997, Chun was sentenced to life in prison and Roh to 17 years.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Although they were later pardoned and freed, Chun and Roh had failed to pay the 220.5 billion won ($203 million) and 268.8 billion won ($248 million) that they were fined, respectively.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Patricia Davis also confirmed her husband’s death in a telephone interview from Niceville, Fla., but declined to say where it had occurred.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: A death certificate issued in Santiago says that a Ray E. Davis died of a “multisystemic failure” on April 30, at age 88.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Records at the Parque del Recuerdo cemetery in Santiago also show that a Ray E. Davis was cremated there but that his remains were taken elsewhere.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Charles Horman’s widow, Joyce, is unconvinced that it is the Ray Davis accused of involvement in her husband’s murder, and she has asked the U.S. Embassy to provide proof of the cancellation of the former captain’s pension.

Sentence: “How is it that no one notified the Chilean court system or the U.S. Embassy that Ray Davis was in Chile, when it now looks like he had been in Chile for a year or so?” she said.

Sentence: DAKAR, Senegal - Charles Blé Goudé, a crucial ally of Laurent Gbagbo, the Ivory Coast strongman indicted on charges of crimes against humanity, is being sought on similar charges, the International Criminal Court said Tuesday.
Label: Main

Sentence: Blé Goudé played a central role in Gbagbo’s efforts to stay in power by force after his defeat in presidential elections in November 2010, recruiting and arming youths who went on to beat and sometimes murder opponents in the economic capital, Abidjan.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He was known as the “general of the streets,” and the youth militia he founded, the Jeunes Patriotes, or Young Patriots, was notorious for its brutality, extortionate checkpoints and frenzied rallies presided over by Blé Goudé.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: An indictment against him, unsealed Tuesday by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, Netherlands, has been pending since December 2011, eight months after he fled Ivory Coast when Gbagbo, the former president, was ousted by the French military.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Blé Goudé was subsequently arrested in Ghana and extradited to Ivory Coast in January of this year.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The indictment accuses him of crimes of humanity including murder and rape and calls him a member of Gbagbo’s inner circle who met with him to receive instructions and formulate plans, playing “a key role in recruiting, enlisting, arming, training and integrating thousands of volunteers” into the army.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The wounds of the brief but bloody 2010-11 civil war - more than 3,000 people died - in Ivory Coast, in which Blé Goudé participated actively, are not healed.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Rural warlords who helped bring Gbagbo’s presidential opponent, Alassane Ouattara, to power still play important military and economic roles, notably in smuggling and in other “predatory economic activities,” according to a report by a United Nations group of experts in April that underlined the country’s political fragility.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Gbagbo’s partisans remain armed; about $400 million in cocoa beans - Ivory Coast is the world’s leading producer and was once West Africa’s economic powerhouse - was lost to smuggling in 2011-12, according to the report.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Long before the civil war, the Jeunes Patriotes had several times been mobilized against forces perceived to be threatening Gbagbo’s power, including the French and the United Nations, with violent results.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Blé Goudé is now being held by the authorities in Ivory Coast, and it is not clear whether they will release him to The Hague.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Eleven days ago they announced that they would not be sending Gbagbo’s wife, Simone, also under indictment, to The Hague, but instead would try her at home.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Human rights activists in Ivory Coast said they doubted that Blé Goudé could receive a fair trial in that country, pointing out, for instance, that his lawyer there has no access to him.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In addition, some of the very rebel leaders who helped Ouattara gain power are accused of crimes similar to those Gbagbo and his associates are accused of.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But so far they have not been arrested.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “We think justice in Ivory Coast is victors’ justice,” said Hervé Gouamene, Blé Goudé’s lawyer in Abidjan.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “Everyone knows crimes were committed on the other side, too.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: There is no impartiality.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation
