Sentence: GENEVA - The U.N. human rights chief, Navi Pillay, on Friday condemned Iraq’s execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week, denouncing such mass executions as “obscene and inhuman” and warning that they undermined efforts to reduce violence and achieve a more stable society.
Label: Main

Sentence: Iraq’s justice system is “too deeply flawed to warrant even a limited use of the death penalty, let alone dozens of executions at a time,” Pillay said in a statement released in Geneva, repeating a view she has expressed on several occasions.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: At least some of the latest executions, which were carried out Wednesday and Thursday, breached international law because Iraq is unable to hold fair trials, Pillay’s spokesman, Rupert Colville, told reporters.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: And Iraq’s decision to proceed with executions Thursday, which was World Day Against the Death Penalty, was “particularly perverse,” Pillay said.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Iraq’s Justice Ministry said the executed prisoners had been convicted of “terrorist crimes, killing dozens of innocents in addition to other crimes aimed at destabilizing the country, causing chaos and spreading horror.”
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Pillay also expressed concern about the “dramatic and shocking increase” in Iraq’s resort to the death penalty.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: This week’s executions brought to 140 the number of people executed so far this year, compared with 123 in 2012 and 18 in 2010, the United Nations reported.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Pillay will be in direct contact with Iraqi authorities in the coming days, Colville said, but in the meantime she urged the government to immediately halt executions and to commute the sentences of about 900 prisoners now held on death row.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: U.N. human rights officials say the integrity of the judicial system has been tainted, citing the numerous reports of confessions obtained through torture and ill-treatment, the weakness of the judiciary and trial procedures that fall far short of international standards.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: They also said some of the offenses for which prisoners are executed did not meet the threshold of “most serious crimes,” which international law sets for the use of the death penalty.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Iraq’s justification for using the death penalty as a deterrent to terrorism was “clearly exposed as a fallacy” by the sharp rise in civilian casualties over the same period, Pillay noted.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The rash of recent bombings in the capital, Baghdad, and other parts of the country had driven up civilian casualties to the highest level since 2008, Pillay observed.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Elisabetta Povoledo contributed reporting from Rome.
Label: NA

Sentence: Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who was sentenced to life in prison for helping to organize the execution of 335 men and boys at the Ardeatine Caves in Italy in 1944, died Friday under house arrest at his home in Rome.
Label: Main

Sentence: He was 100 and the oldest surviving convicted Nazi war criminal.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: He “died of old age,” said his lawyer, Paolo Giachini.
Label: Cause_Specific

Sentence: Priebke was at the center of one of the most contentious Nazi war-crimes prosecutions of the 1990s, begun after an American television crew tracked him down in Argentina at San Carlos de Bariloche, a resort city in the foothills of the Andes.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Priebke fled to South America soon after World War II and had been living under his real name, owning a butcher shop and traveling to Europe - and even Italy - with a German passport.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He was extradited to Italy in November 1995 and ordered to stand trial before an Italian military tribunal the next year.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The proceedings - described at the time as possibly the last Nazi war-crimes trial in Europe - centered on the massacre at the Ardeatine Caves, just south of Rome, on March 24, 1944.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The men and boys were rounded up and killed in reprisal for an attack in which Italian partisans killed 33 members of a Nazi security force.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Herbert Kappler, the Gestapo chief in Rome, ordered the deaths of 10 Italians for every dead policeman.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Seventy-five of the 335 victims were Jewish.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: By many accounts, the captives were led into the caves with their hands tied behind their backs, forced to kneel - many over the bodies of those already killed - and shot in the neck.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Priebke said he was responsible for exceeding the quota by five.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: “It went wrong,” he was quoted as saying in an article published in the German newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung a week before his death.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The prosecution in Italy was a protracted affair.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The military tribunal that tried Priebke in 1996 ended up ordering him freed.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: While finding him guilty of involvement in the massacre, the court acquitted him of acting with premeditation and cruelty.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Only a conviction on those counts would have sent him to prison because of a 30-year statute of limitations on murder charges.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: His release caused an international outcry, and he was rearrested after an appellate court ordered another trial by military tribunal.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In July 1997, the second military court sentenced him to 15 years in prison, but reduced that term to five years, saying there had been mitigating factors, including Priebke’s assertion that he had acted under orders.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Prosecutors appealed, and in March 1998 Priebke was sentenced to life, a verdict that was upheld by the Court of Cassation, Italy’s highest appellate court.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Because of his age, Priebke was put under house arrest.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Two soldiers kept watch day and night outside the apartment block in western Rome where Priebke lived, and two police officers followed him whenever he left the residence, according to the account in Sueddeutsche Zeitung, by Malte Herwig.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Referring to Hannah Arendt’s famous phrase about the Nazis when she covered the trial of Adolf Eichmann in Israel, Herwig, who has done extensive research on the Nazi era, described his encounter with Priebke as “the last chance to investigate that supposed banality of evil with a living person.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Priebke was born on July 29, 1913, in Hennigsdorf, near Berlin.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: His parents both died early in his life, he told Herwig, and he was reared largely by an uncle.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Little is known of his early life.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: As World War II ended, he was imprisoned by the British but eventually fled to a German-speaking area in the north of Italy, where he reunited with his wife and two sons, according to Herwig.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The family fled by way of Genoa to Argentina, where Priebke worked as a waiter and then opened a butcher shop.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: His commander at the time of the massacre, Kappler, was sentenced to life in prison in 1948 by a Rome court.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He was smuggled out of a military hospital in 1997 and died in freedom in Germany the following year.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Karl Hass, an SS major, was convicted with Priebke in July 1997 and given a life sentence in 1998.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: He died while under house arrest in 2004.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Priebke is survived by his two sons and several grandchildren and great-grandchildren.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: His lawyer said he would be buried in Argentina.
Label: Main_Consequence

Sentence: In recent years, Priebke remained a rallying point both for neo-Nazis and their opponents.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In July, members of Jewish groups and other protesters gathered near his home on the occasion of his 100th birthday to read the names of the massacre’s victims.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: To the end of his life, Priebke expressed no remorse for his actions.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: The law firms Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe and Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman are in advanced merger talks, with an announcement of a deal expected as early as next week.
Label: Main

Sentence: A combination would create one of the country’s 10 largest firms with about 1,700 lawyers.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: The discussions underscore the pressure on corporate law firms to grow their businesses amid persistently soft demand for legal services and the increasing globalization of the corporate law industry.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: “Our firms are in exploratory discussions about a possible combination,” James Rishwain, the chairman of Pillsbury, and Mitch Zuklie, the chairman of Orrick, said in a joint statement.
Label: Main

Sentence: “These talks are serving to confirm the great respect our firms have for each other.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: People close to the talks said that the deal could still fall apart but that they were far along.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Typically, the executive committees of each firm agree to the main terms of a merger and then the entire partnerships vote at a later date.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: The news was first reported by Reuters.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Mergers among the nation’s 100 largest firms once occurred infrequently, and marriages involving top firms were rarer still.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: But today, firms are under pressure to add to their practices quickly to break into new geographic markets and practice areas.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: And some legal industry studies have concluded that size matters in corporate law - the larger the firm, the stronger the brand.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Law firm mergers are booming, and a combination of Orrick and Pillsbury would be the year’s largest.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Fifty-eight law firms had announced mergers as of the end of September, a 41 percent increase from the same period last year, according to survey by Altman Weil, a legal industry consulting firm.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: In 2012, the large Houston firm, Fulbright & Jaworksi, joined forces with Norton Rose in Britain, creating a firm of nearly 4,000 lawyers.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Dentons, a firm of about 2,500 lawyers, is in talks to acquire McKenna Long & Aldridge in a deal that would push its lawyer count to more than 3,000.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: But law firm mergers carry significant risk.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: For starters, there is a possibility that the leaking of merger talks can have a destabilizing effect on the firms involved, leading to defections by important partners who may disapprove of a deal or fear a lesser role - or less compensation - at the combined firm.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Big law firm deals have a mixed track record and often result in power struggles and cultural clashes.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Most infamously, the 2007 merger of Dewey Ballantine and LeBoeuf Lamb Greene & MacRae - the largest merger of New York law firms in history - was a fiasco.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Last year, the combined firm, Dewey & LeBoeuf, collapsed in bankruptcy amid financial mismanagement and partner defections.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In 2006, Orrick had flirted with possible disaster when it had agreed to the main terms of a combination with Dewey Ballantine, but the deal fell apart after several top partners jumped ship when merger talks were leaked.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Orrick, with 1,100 lawyers, has talked with several firms over the past decade but never made it to the altar.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Pillsbury, too, recently discussed a deal with Fulbright.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Although today each has offices across the globe, both Orrick’s and Pillsbury’s historical roots are firmly grounded on the West Coast.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Each was started in San Francisco in the 1860s in the wake of the California gold rush.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: A merger would create a formidable presence in Silicon Valley, which has become an area of expansion for corporate firms.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: In Washington, Pillsbury has an especially strong nuclear energy practice, another hot practice area.
Label: Cause_General

Sentence: Newsweek, the struggling weekly magazine that ceased print publication last year, plans to turn the presses back on.
Label: Main

Sentence: The magazine will begin a 64-page, weekly edition in January or February, said Jim Impoco, Newsweek’s editor in chief.
Label: Main

Sentence: He said in an interview that Newsweek would depend more heavily on subscribers than advertisers to pay its bills and that readers would pay more for Newsweek than in the past.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: “It’s going to be a more subscription-based model, closer to what The Economist is, compared to what Time magazine is,” Impoco said.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: “We see it as a premium product, a boutique product.”
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Newsweek’s return to print is a positive sign for a magazine that struggled mightily in the digital age.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: At its height in 1991, the magazine had 3.3 million readers.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In 2010, Newsweek’s owner, The Washington Post, sold it to billionaire investor Sidney Harman for $1.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Harman, who also assumed $40 million in liabilities, then merged it with The Daily Beast, the website owned by IAC/InterActiveCorp.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Editor Tina Brown took control of the combined titles, but the venture failed.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: The traditional Newsweek never properly blended with The Daily Beast.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Brown announced in October 2012 that Newsweek would no longer publish a magazine, saving $40 million a year, and would continue as an online-only magazine called Newsweek Global.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Still, removing those print costs did not mean Newsweek had found a solution.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: In May, Brown announced that IAC/InterActiveCorp planned to sell Newsweek, so that the company could focus its attention on The Daily Beast.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: IBT Media - a small, digital media company - bought Newsweek in August.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: In September, Brown stepped down from The Daily Beast and said she was leaving publishing entirely.
Label: Distant_Historical

Sentence: Impoco, who became Newsweek’s editor in September, said that the magazine’s new owner would not have to spend as much money publishing it as the previous owner.
Label: Distant_Evaluation

Sentence: Impoco said that IBT was negotiating with printers and distributors and hoped to build Newsweek’s circulation to 100,000 in the first year.
Label: Distant_Expectations_Consequences

Sentence: Since taking the helm, Impoco, a former editor at The New York Times, has made more than two dozen new hires and is looking to expand Newsweek’s international coverage.
Label: Cause_General
